loans.name: Najma

texts.en: Najma is a 32-year-old lady who enjoys doing hand embroidery on leather sheets for shoe making. She receives orders from the shoe-making factory and earns a reasonable amount of income to support her family. She has five children and is trying hard to fulfill their demands including food, health, clothing and education. To fulfill the orders of her customers on time, she has applied for a loan of Rs 20,000 through Kashf Foundation. This loan will help her to purchase leather with some spools of thread and packs of beads. In this way, she can manage to complete orders on time and earn enough income to support her family well.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of leather, some spools of thread and packs of beads.

loans.name: Maurice Bertrand

texts.en: Maurice is a Cameroonian, 38, living in a rural area. He is married with three children. The oldest is seven years and the youngest is three years old and in primary school. He has been in business for over a year now, which makes him stable, experienced and successful. This is his first loan with us. This loan will help him increase his profit by about 28 percent and hence, his standard of living.

loans.use: to pay for provision store items to sell

loans.name: Razia

texts.en: Razia is a 52-year-old married woman who has been selling milk for the past five years. She has three calves and two buffaloes in milk. She sells their milk to many of her neighbors, along with butter that she makes from the milk. Her business is good enough to lead a decent life. She has three children. She is very motivated to provide them a beautiful life with a good education, food and clothing.  She has improved her business to meet the day-to-day expenses of life. It’s her seventh year with Kashf Foundation. She is happily running her business through support for it. Now she requested a loan of Rs 35,000 to purchase another buffalo and feed for its calves. She hopes to get an increase in the production capacity of milk to increase her sales.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo and feed for its calves.

loans.name: Sughran

texts.en:
Sughran is a 43-year old, vigorous married woman. She has been involved in the business of hand-embroidery for the past six years. She is passionate about her work, and client demand is strong. But business challenges, combined with family expenditures, frustrate her nearly every day. Her husband is a laborer, but he does not earn enough to support his family well. She is a mother of four children and is responsible for their food, health and education, and is trying hard to fulfill their basic necessities through her business. 

At this time, she requested a loan of 30,000 rupees to buy raw materials such as colorful threads, sequins, unique stones and pearls in large quantities. It will help her to meet the orders of her customers on time. She shared her dream of running a training center for girls of her area.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as colorful threads, sequins, unique stones and pearls in large quantities.

loans.name: Abida

texts.en: Abida is a 27-year-old energetic lady. She has been actively involved in the business of hand-embroidery for the past six years with the support of Kashf Foundation. Her embroidery patterns are very famous in her locality, and her demand is increasing day by day. But due to lack of availability of funds, she is not able to fulfill the demands of her customers. For this reason, she is requesting a loan of 30,000 rupees to buy raw material such as frames, needles, sequins, threads of different colors, unique pearls and stones. She is in her fourth loan cycle with a good repayment history. She expects an increase in profits and hopes to save some money to provide better living standards to her family.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as frames, needles, sequins, threads of different colors, unique pearls and stones.

loans.name: Zahidan

texts.en: Zahidan has expertise in embroidery and has been using her skill to provide for her family for over 14 years now. During the initial years of her business she barely made enough money to purchase the required material. Today she is proud to be famous in her community to be the best at making beautiful patterns with thread and beads. To meet the orders of her customers on time, she requested another loan of PKR 20,000 to purchase more spools of thread with packs of beads, sequins and glittering material in various colors. She is in her third loan cycle with a good repayment history. She says that the females in her community are becoming demanding with the passage of time and satisfying them is a challenge that Zahidan has taken up.

loans.use: to purchase more spools of thread with packs of beads, sequins and glittering material in various colors.

loans.name: Dominic

texts.en:
Dominic is a 25-year-old single man with no dependants. He is a carpenter who owns a workshop, a business he started three years ago, and earns a monthly income of KES 20,000. He has requested a second loan of KES 30,000 to purchase timber, plywood and paints to use in his workshop. 

The profit he earns will help him to expand this business as well as to repay his loan. He hopes to see his business grow and have a neat and healthy family in future.

loans.use: to purchase timber, plywood and paints.

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick is a 30-year-old man from Nyalenda in Kisumu county. He is married to Stella and they have two children aged four and two years old respectively.

He has been running a barber shop for the last five years and makes a monthly income of KES 20,000. He has applied for his second loan with KADET LTD, which he will use to purchase more machines and repair his shop. He will use the anticipated profit to plow back into the business.

His dream is expand his business and take care of his family.

loans.use: To purchase machines and repair his shop.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose used her previous loan to buy shutters. She has paid it very well and has applied for another one such that she could buy materials to do an extension of her veranda, to provide a good shed for resting and also drying ground. 

She is grateful that Kiva lenders through UGAFODE have been contributing to her family's well being. She is a hard working lady who loves to see her family progressing. The veranda will also help to protect the face of her house.

loans.use: To buy cement and labour for work on her veranda

loans.name: Wesley

texts.en:
Wesley lives in the Litein area of Kenya. He has 1 child and has been doing this work for 5 years.  His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Profit gained from farm products.' His biggest challenge is 'Feeding poultry.' Animals on the farm have been given no names.

Wesley was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: 'it offers grace period.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'It's dedicated to improving farmer's livelihood.'

His highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked 'How will this loan benefit his family', Wesley replied 'I will educate them.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Wesley owns the following: 'cow, poultry, motorcycle' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net, electricity, TV, DVD' but does not have 'solar power, running water, sewing machine'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase poultry

loans.name: Manushak

texts.en:
Manushak is 40 years old. She lives in Akhaltsikhe District with her sister and niece. Manushak has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Manushak has requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Manushak has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With her credit Manushak will begin selling bed linen. She plans to go to Turkey and purchase bed linen at wholesale prices and then resell among her villagers at a higher price. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to begin selling bed linen

loans.name: Sirvard

texts.en:
Sirvard is from Surenavan village of Ararat region where she lives with her son and his family. Sirvard has been running a farm for many years. In particular she cultivates tomatoes and grows different types of fruit trees (apricot, peach, and apple). Over time, she has become famous in her area for providing good-quality products. She has a good client list and makes enough to contribute to her family's income. Sirvard has a two-year-old grandchild (in the photo) and is very motivated to provide him a beautiful life, food and clothing.
 
In order to continue running her farm, Sirvard needs to purchase seeds and fertilizer, which is very important for successful cultivation of the land. For this purpose, Sirvard has requested this loan. The other part of the loan will be used for covering watering costs. The loan is very important for Sirvard to gather more income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for seeds and fertilizer and cover watering costs

loans.name: Jareti

texts.en:
Jareti is a 50-year-old married man. He supports a family of three children aged between seven and 22 years. His spouse supports him in meeting some of their financial needs. Jareti runs a transport business in Kapsabet town and he has been in this business for the last eight years.

Jareti has borrowed KES 90,000 from KADET LTD. With this loan he intends to purchase a new motorbike to expand his transport service business. From this business he gets an average profit of KES 13,000 each month. 

With the anticipated profits he intends to expand his business by starting a dairy farming business to diversify his sources of income, and also to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Rubik

texts.en:
Rubik has a small and beautiful farm which he takes care of with great pleasure and enthusiasm. He has two bulls, one heifer and one calf. Rubik’s wife helps him very much with the farming activities. They live in a small nice city, Gavar, in the Gavar area. Rubik is 60 years old and he has four grown-up children, three daughters and a son. They are all married and live separately with their families. Rubik completed higher education; he graduated from Gavar State University. 
It is Rubik’s first loan and he wants to borrow an amount of 500,000 Armenian drams for the purchase of one cow and animal fodder. He and his family hope very much that Kiva lenders will give him an opportunity to enrich both his farm and his family income.

loans.use: to buy one cow and animal fodder

loans.name: Walter

texts.en:
Walter is a 52-year-old man, married to Lucy and a father of seven children. Two of the children are over eighteen years and do not live with him. He is a farmer and also sells groceries. He has been in this business for fourteen years and gets a monthly income of KES 25,000.

This will be Walter's seventh loan from KADET LTD. He plans to use the loan to buy fertilizer and animal feeds. In future he wants to own more cows and also be a well-known dairy farmer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and animal feeds

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is 61 years old, married to Abraham and blessed with four children aged 32, 28, 26 and 22 years respectively. She practices farming which she has been doing for the past 10 years in order to earn a living. She earns a monthly income of KES 50,000. 

She has requested a second loan of KES 100,000 to purchase fertilizer and seeds for the planting season. The profit she earns will contribute towards her buying more land. She dreams of becoming a renowned farmer in this region.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seeds for the planting season.

loans.name: Jaime Rufino

texts.es:
Jaime es un hombre de 29 años, es soltero, vive en la ciudad de Ica, el es una persona muy amable, trabajador y entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo de superación; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad que tuvo de trabajar desde muy joven Jaime no pudo estudiar la carrera profesional de Mecánica, en sus ratos libres le gusta cocinar un riquísimo Arroz con Pollo para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, Jaime trabaja como albañil, realizando obras de construcción, como casas, habitaciones, y otros, el trabaja todos los días desde tempranas horas de la mañana y puede hacerlo por un aproximado de 10 horas, adicionalmente los fines de semana trabaja como chofer de taxi, brindando servicios de transporte, Jaime se siente a gusto realizando su labor y cree que le va bien por los buenos precios y por el trato amable que brinda a los demás.
Jaime se encuentra muy agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de herramientas, como madera, una carretilla, martillos y otros, los cuales le servirán de mucho para poder seguir realizando sus trabajos de construcción, así pues Jaime seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de tener su casas propia.
texts.en:
Jaime, 29, is a single man that lives in the city of Ica. He is a kind, hardworking and enthusiastic person, with a strong will to succeed. Unfortunately, due to the lack of economic resources and because he had to work since he was young, Jaime could not study Mechanics. During his free time, he enjoys cooking a delicious “rice with chicken” to share it with his family.

He took the initiative to work as a mason, something he does with commitment and dedication. He does different types of works in houses, rooms, etc. Jaime starts working early in the morning, every day, and does it for approximately ten hours. During the weekends, he works as a taxi driver. Jaime likes his job and believes that he does well because he offers good prices and is kind to others.

Jaime feels grateful to Kiva lenders, since with the help he received he will be able to buy things he needs for his job, such as wood, a wheelbarrow and a hammer. These things will be very useful to continue with his works. He will continue working hard in order to make his dream come true: to have a house of his own.

loans.use: to buy tools and materials.

loans.name: Lucio

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al Banco Comunal “Amistad Cusqueña”, él socio continua brindando el servicio de taxi, el socio lleva buen tiempo dedicándose a esta actividad el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su trabajo, él socio a la vez continua con su negocio de restaurante siendo de esta forma que el socio saca adelante a su familia.
El socio solicita el crédito para realizar el mantenimiento de su carro.

El socio se siente agradecido por el crédito y se compromete a pagar sus cuotas puntualmente.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the Communal Bank "Amistad Cusqueña". He continues with his taxi service. He has dedicated himself to this activity for a long time, and it's going well for him thanks to the effort that he puts into his work every day. At the same time, he continues with his restaurant business, which is the way in which he supports his family.

This member feels very grateful for this loan and is committed to paying his monthly installments on time.

loans.use: to perform maintenance on his car.

loans.name: Sofyan

texts.en:
Sofyan runs a 'warung', a small Indonesian shop, selling snacks, drinks and other small items in Bogor.  Bogor is about 2 hours away from Jakarta.  Sofyan’s shop is not just a typical 'warung', Sofyan is also a part of the Ruma Network, selling mobile phone airtime credit and processing bill payments for customers.  Sofyan is excited to be a part of this network because he hopes that these services will bring more customers to the shop and increase his income.  

Sofyan lives with his wife and 2 children.  Since joining Ruma, Sofyan is earning on average $30/per day in mobile airtime credit sales.  With the support and assistance from Ruma staff, he hopes to grow his business even more.  

Sofyan is now offering to process electricity bill payments for customers as a new service.  To do this, he is required to print receipts for these transactions.  He is requesting a Kiva loan to help him to purchase the printer so he can offer this new service.

loans.use: To purchase a printer for printing out the required receipts for mobile phone credit sales and bill payment transactions

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en:
Kalsoom had a difficult time after her husband's business failure. She decided to work with her husband to support her family for a better future. 

Five years ago, Kalsoom began sewing shoe uppers in her house. She supplies these uppers to different factories where they are used in making shoes. As a result, she now earns enough money to contribute to the family's income. However, due to a lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet the orders of her customers on time. This is why she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for her second loan of PKR 30,000 to buy leather and spools of thread in large quantities. This will help her to increase her sales. 

Kalsoom is very experienced in her business. She is confident that her business will move toward a positive direction as a result of this loan investment.

loans.use: to buy leather and spools of thread in large quantities.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie signed up for membership to PMPC this year. She is married with 2 children. Elsie is 38 years old and lives in Poblacion, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay. She operates her sari-sari store to earn a living and has had this business for 5 years. Each month, she earns 3,000 PHP doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for 11,000 PHP for additional capital.

In the future, Elsie hopes to expand her business and wants to live comfortably with her family.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a 32-year-old mother from Manyatta in the county of Kisumu. She is married to Jorim, a businessman who provides financial support to the family. She is blessed with four children, ages 19, 15, 13 and 12.

Florence sells charcoal, a business she has been doing for the last 15 years. She makes a monthly income of KES 60,000. She has applied for her ninth loan, which she will use to purchase more sacks of charcoal in bulk from the suppliers located outside of Kisumu. She will use the anticipated profits to start a new business.

Her dream is to become a successful entrepreneur and support her family.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a 44-year-old man who is married to Mary has five children. He has been in the taxi business in Kangemi for six years now. He earns monthly income of 35,000 shillings.

This will be Stephen's second loan with KADET LTD. He plans to use the loan to pay school fees for his children. In the future he wants to be a successful businessman and also continue paying school fees for the children.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Vibian

texts.en:
Vibian is a 35-year-old married woman who supports a family of three children that are between one and eight years old. She runs milk and vegetables business in Kapsabet. This has been her income generating business for the last three years, and she earns an average monthly profit of KES. 10,000.

She has requested a loan of KES. 30,000, and with it she intends to purchase more stocks of milk and vegetables and other food items, like potatoes. She anticipates earning profits that she will use to expand her business by opening a small cantine to sale cakes as well as fermented milk.

Vibian hopes to improve her living standards and be financially stable. She also hopes to save money to enable her to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to purchase milk and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Arlyn works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling eggs in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs and ducks. Arlyn is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to purchase additional trays of eggs to sell in her business.

Arlyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: purchase additional trays of eggs to sell.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a hardworking entrepreneur, who has a tailoring business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for six years. She earns additional income by selling ready-to-wear clothing and providing printing services.

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF. She will use the loan to buy materials for her tailoring business. She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan, to build her tailoring business further. Lydia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is 39 years old and married with five children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Thelma is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to buy additional feeds for her pig.

Thelma has been raising pigs for five years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional feeds for her pigs.

loans.name: Marciana

texts.en:
Marciana works hard to support her family. She is married and has a business selling used shoes and clothing, in the Philippines. She has been in this business for nine years.

Marciana requested a PHP 22,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. She will use the loan to purchase more stock of used shoes and clothing to resell. Marciana would like to build and expand her business, in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of used shoes and clothing to resell

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Shirley works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from pig raising. Shirley is borrowing 25,000 PHP through NWTF to buy items to sell like soap, sugar, milk, canned good, spices, etc., for her general store business.

Shirley has been sustaining her business activities through her past 20 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like soap, sugar, milk, canned good, spices, etc.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John works hard to support his family. He is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines. He has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional equipment for his business, which he has had for 8 years now. In the future, John would like to save enough money so he can afford to send his children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional equipment for his business.

loans.name: Regia

texts.en:
Regia is a 42-year-old separated mother of five from Israel’s Negev region. She works part-time as a kindergarten teacher and has a clothing store, which is open in the afternoons and evenings. The store is located on a main street and has a good customer base. However, Regia needs to update her stock to meet her customers' demands.

She needs this loan to pay for electrical work, lighting and new stock of clothes.

Regia wants to continue and strengthen her business but, most importantly, she wants to ensure her children’s education and strong future.

loans.use: To pay for electrical work, lighting and new stock of clothes.

loans.name: Rosa Estela

texts.es:
Rosa es una mujer de 27 años de edad, casada, tiene una hermosa hija de 9 años de edad; ellos viven en  el Caserío Chuacruz, municipio de San José Chacayá, departamento de Sololá.
Ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pan. Cuenta con un local en el centro del municipio de Sololá en donde les vende a sus clientes pan caliente todos los días. Esta actividad la aprendió de su esposo y la realiza porque le genera buenas ganancias que le ayudan a brindarle alimentación, ropa y educación a su hija. Tiene 8 años de estar realizando esta actividad.
Ella solicita un préstamo de Q 10,000.00 para compra de una computadora (tiene una computadora ya obsoleta) para que su hija pueda realizar sus trabajos estudiantiles que le son requeridos todos los días.
Sueña con ampliar la venta de pan y apoyar a su hija en sus estudios y que en un futuro sean una profesional.
texts.en:
Rosa, 27, is married and has a beautiful nine-year-old daughter. They live in the community of Chuacruz, which is located in the municipality of San José Chacayá, Sololá department.

Rosa makes and sells bread. She has an establishment in the city center of Sololá, where she sells warm bread to her customers every day. She learned from her husband and works with it because it leaves good profits that help her to provide for her daughter. She has been doing this for eight years.

She is requesting a loan of Q 10,000 [GTQ] to buy a computer (the one she has is obsolete). With this computer, her daughter will be able to work on her daily school projects.

Rosa’s dreams are to expand her business and support her daughter so that she can study and become a professional in the future.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
Abibatu is 25 years old and married with 2 children who are 3 and 7 years old. She runs a plastic home products business in Tombo, an area in western rural Sierra Leone.

She's been in this business since 2008 and sells bowels, spoons and food containers within her community. She says that the main problem in her business is lack of capital to expand.

Abibatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more home products for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to buy a plot of land. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more home products for resale.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Meet 30-year-old Patricia from Tombo, a rural area in western Sierra Leone. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 3 months and 10 years old. Two of her children are currently attending school. In 2000, Patricia established her soft drinks business. She began her business because she needed to create an income to improve her standard of living. She works 7 days a week, 12 hours per day. She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation.

Patricia requires a loan in order to buy more pure water and soft drinks for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to take good care of her family and increase her business. In the future, Patricia plans to build a permanent residence for her family. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more pure water and soft drinks for resale.

loans.name: Sokun

texts.en:
A married mother of three children living in the Ponhea Leur district of Kandal province, Sokun is 47 years old and she sells grocery items while her husband grows rice on three hectares of farmland to support their entire family. For 10 years in this business, she and her husband are able to earn up to KHR 25,000 per day and keep aside KHR 10,000 each day as savings. 

Sokun joined VisionFund Kiva’s partner one loan cycle ago. She fully paid back the past loan which helped her better support her current business and improved her family livelihood. She is now applying for a loan to pay her son’s university tuition. She hopes this loan will enable her to keep up her son’s education until graduation so he can make a better living in the future.

loans.use: To pay her son’s university tuition

loans.name: Srouy's Group

texts.en:
Residing in a rural village of Battambang province’s Moung Russey district, Srouy is a 51-year-old married mother of four children, one of whom is still in school. Srouy and her husband have been earning a living farming rice for 20 years. They earn about 23,000 KHR per day and manage to save about 15,000          KHR daily for future needs.

Srouy has been with VisionFund for five cycles and has completely repaid her past loans, while the other member has been with VisionFund for six cycles. Srouy used the past loans to better support her family and increase her family’s business. Now she is leading her group to apply for another loan, her portion of which she will use to buy fertilizers for her farmland and pay for the labor involved in plowing the field. 

Srouy hopes to grow her rice successfully and expand her current business to better her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Det's Group

texts.en:
Living in a wooden house located in the Moung Russey district of Battambang province, Det is 33 years old and married. He has two children, both of whom are dependents. To make a living, he and his wife have been farming rice for 10 years. The current business earns them about 12,000 KHR per day and enables them to save about 5,000 KHR each day for their future needs.
 
This is the third micro loan for Det with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. The other members are just with VisionFund this cycle. He completely repaid the past two loans, which have helped him make his living better. He is now leading his group to request a loan with VisionFund of 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, he wants to use his portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for his farmland. With this loan, he hopes to grow his business and earn a larger income to improve his standard of living and send and keep his children in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for his farmland

loans.name: Sreyoeurn

texts.en: Sreyoeurn, a hardworking mother blessed with three children who are students in a local state school, is 35 years old and a local villager from Kandal Stoeung district of Kandal province. She deals with the daily cost of living by tailoring clothe, paddy rice growing, and vegetable planting. She has just been involved in her current business for two years, earning about 18,800 KHR per day. This is not the first microloan for Sreyoeurn with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has fully repaid her past loan with success and it has enabled her to support her business promptly and relieve her family's burden. Now, she is applying for a new loan in order to buy an additional plot of farmland and a water pump, and to use a portion of it to support her vegetable garden. She hopes to grow her cash crops healthily so that she can gain a high, good yield with a good selling price.

loans.use: To buy an additional plot of farmland and a water pump

loans.name: Hoert's Group

texts.en:
Hoert is 21 years old and married with two children, both of whom are dependents and still small. She lives in a rural village in the Moung Russey district where crop farming is a common way to make a living. Like other villagers, rice farming and pineapple growing have been her family’s main source of income. The current business earns her about 22,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. 

Hoert’s group consists of two members who are both female. She has been a member of VisionFund for one cycle already. The past loan has helped her family with sufficient food and better support the business. Now she is leading her group to apply for a loan. Hoert wants to use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes to grow her rice and pineapple fruitfully and healthily to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland

loans.name: Mas

texts.en:
A farmer who grows rice on one hectare area and comes from Pursat Province,Sampov Meas district, Mas is a widowed mother of five children. Aged 41, she still needs to support some of her children as they are still in school. She has been with this business for 30 years and is able to earn up to 33,300 KHR per day.

 Mas, a sixth-time borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner), has utilized her past loans wisely to manage her business and the necessary demands in her family. Now, she is seeking a new loan of 4,000,000 KHR in order to buy rice seed, cows, four sacks of potash, and to pay for reaping fee. She also plans to buy a decent motorbike for commuting in her family. She truly believes that she can make triple income from her business, earning more than before.

loans.use: To buy a decent motorbike, rice seed, cows, four sacks of potash, and to pay reaping fees

loans.name: Samem

texts.en:
Samem, a rural villager from Kandal province's Ponhea Luer district, is 20 years old. To support the family, she is a nursing assistant in a village. She has been working this part-time job for one year. She can earn approximately KHR 25,000 per day to better support her family and she can manage to save about KHR 10,000 each day, after daily expenses. 

Samem has been with VisionFund Cambodia for one cycle. She completely paid back the past loan which helped her provide better support to her family members with enough food. 

This cycle, she is applying for an education loan in amount of 750 U.S. Dollars to cover the entire tuition fee in a local university specializing in midwife services. She hopes that this loan will enable her to obtain a higher education background and end up with a good job after graduation in order to support the family.

loans.use: to cover her entire tuition fee.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Living in a rural village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province, Sam is aged 51 years and widowed. Sam has been earning a living through farming rice for ten years. The current business earns her about KHR 45,000 per day, and she can save about KHR 25,000 each day for future needs.
 
Sam has been with VisionFund for six cycles and fully repaid her loans, which have helped her better support her family. Now she is applying for a loan of KHR 3,000,000 to buy fertilizer and gasoline for her farmland, and to use a portion of it to spend on labor fees. 

Sam hopes to grow her current business so as to increase her family’s income to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and gasoline for her farmland.

loans.name: Sophos

texts.en:
Sophos is 25 years old, living with her family in a rural village located in the Kandieng district of Pursat province. She is married and has no children. 

Sophos has been running a wedding embellishment service in a local area, while her husband is a sculptor to earn additional income. The current business earns her about KHR 70,000 per day to meet the family needs. 

This is the first loan for Sophos with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund Cambodia. Now she is requesting a loan of KHR 2,000,000 to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes to grow her rice healthily and fruitfully, so as to sell it for a good price, to improve her family’s lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland.

loans.name: Seak's Group

texts.en:
A mother four children from Kror Kor district of Pursat Province, Seak is 34 years old and makes a living via one hectare and a half of rice farming and a pig-raising business. The eight years engagement in the current business has provided her a decent income, 13,200 KHR per day. 

This is not the first loan for Seak with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). The past loans, which she has fully repaid, have sustained her business and her lifestyle in a good condition, especially providing her sufficient food for her family. 

Now, she and her fellow group member are seeking 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy a decent motorbike for commuting in her family. She hopes that this purchase will support her business on time so that she can earn more income to keep her children in school.

loans.use: To buy a decent motorbike for commuting in her family

loans.name: Chhoern

texts.en: A resident of a rural village in Dambae District, Chhoern is a 30-year-old mother of two children. The main sources of the family’s income are rice farming on one hectare of farmland and cassava planting on two hectares of farmland. She has been engaged in these activities for ten years. With her current business, she can earn about KHR 41,000 per day to spend on daily expenses. She had her first loan from Kiva partner VisionFund. Now she is applying for another loan of 2,000,000 KHR to buy pesticides and fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her income and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy pesticides and fertilizer for her farm.

loans.name: Sun's Group

texts.en:
Sun is 57 years old and married with five children. She and her group member live in a village of the Cheung Prey district of Kampong Cham province. To make a living, she and her husband have been farming rice for 35 years, earning about 40,000 KHR per day.

Sun is just now with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, this cycle. Now she is leading her group to apply for a loan of 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, Sun wants to use her portion to buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland. She hopes to grow her crops better and produce higher yields in order for her to increase her family’s income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Theavy's Group

texts.en:
Living in a rural area located in Kampong Cham province’s Ponhea Krek district, Theavy is a 26-year-old mother of one son, who is still small. She is a rice farmer in the local area and she supplements her family’s income by growing cassava. Having been in the business for five years, she can make daily income from her current business of KHR 14,000 and she is able to save about KHR 7,000 per day, after expenses, for the future needs.

This is the fourth loan for Theavy with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund Cambodia. She completely paid back the past loan which has helped her to relieve her family’s burden and improve her livelihood. Now, she is leading her group to ask for a loan of KHR 500,000 each. 

As the leader, Theavy is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes to earn more income from her rice paddy, so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Taing's Group

texts.en:
Taing, 39, is a widower with three children residing in a rural village of the Sa Ang district of Kandal province. Two of his children are dependents and still in school. 

To support the family, he has been working very hard as a construction worker for 16 years. He can earn about KHR 13,000 per day and can save about KHR 5,000 each day for future needs.

Taing has been with VisionFund for one cycle and completely paid back the past loan, which helped him better support his children with enough food. Now he is leading his group of four to apply for another loan. Taing will use his portion to buy construction materials for supporting his business. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his income so as to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for supporting his business.

loans.name: Chanthida's Group

texts.en:
Chanthida, 31, lives with her husband and three children in a rural village of the Prey Chhor district of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. All of her children are dependent on her. Two of them are still in school, while the other one is still small. 

Chanthida has struggled to feed and care for her children by farming rice on 2.5-hectares of farmland. She has been in this business for 15 years, while her husband is a paid worker in the local area. Together, they can earn about KHR 45,000 per day and manage to save about KHR 17,000 each day for the future.

Chanthida has been with VisionFund Cambodia for two cycles and completely paid back the past loans which have helped her to have enough household supplies. Now, she is leading her group to ask for another loan with VisionFund Cambodia. 

Chanthida wants to use her portion to buy seeds, fertilizer, and pesticides for her farmland. She hopes to grow her rice healthily and to earn more healthy crops in the future to make a better living and to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer, and pesticides for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Sokhem's Group

texts.en:
Sokhem lives in a rural village of the Tbaung Khmum district of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is 25 years old and married with one daughter who is still in school. To support her family, she has been working as a farmer for six years, growing cassava and rice on one-hectare of farmland. The current business earns her about 19,000 KHR per day and enables her to save 9,000 KHR each day after expenses. 
Now she is leading her Sokhem's Group of two female members to apply for a loan with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. This is her first loan with VisionFund while the other member has been with VisionFund for four loans. Sokhem will use her portion to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to grow healthier rice and cassava to increase her family’s income to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Thea

texts.en:
Living in a rural village from the Tbaung Khmum district of Cambodia, Thea is aged 32 years and married with five children, one of whom is still in school. She is a hard-working farmer who earns a living through farming sesame and cassava. To gain more income to better support the family, she raises fish for selling. Thea can earn about 24,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. 

Thea has been with VisionFund for two cycles and completely paid back the past loans. The loans from VisionFund have helped her family expand the family’s businesses. Now requesting a loan of KHR 2,000,000, she will use this loan to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland and use a portion of it to spend on water pumping. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her business to make more income so as to make a living better.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Nhanh's Group

texts.en:
Nhanh, 23, is a married woman, living with her two children in a rural village of the Srey Snom district of Siem Reap province, Cambodia. 

She earns a living through farming rice on two hectares of farmland. Having been in this business for five years, she is able to earn about KHR 10,000 per day and she can manage to save about KHR 5,000 each day, after deducting daily expenses. 

Nhanh has been with VisionFund Cambodia for one cycle and completely paid back the past loan which helped her relieve her family’s burden and improve her livelihood. 

Now, she is leading her group, Nhanh's Group, to ask for a loan. Nhanh will use her portion to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn a large income from her rice paddy, so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for her farmland.

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Srey Snom district

loans.name: Nhanh's Group

texts.en:
Originally from a rural village of Battambang province’s Moung Russey district, Nhanh is a 31-year-old mother of three children, one of whom is in school while the others are too young for school. She is a rice farmer and supplements her income by working as a paid worker in the village to make a living. With both jobs she can earn about 33,000 KHR per day and can manage to save about 20,000KHR each day.

Nhanh’s group consists of five members, and she has been with VisionFund for three cycles. She has completely paid back her loans with VisionFund. The past loans have helped her to better support her family. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer, pesticides and seed for her farmland. She hopes to make more crops so as to sell at a good price to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and seed for her farmland.

loans.name: Hien

texts.en:
Hien is 31 years old. She has two children. The oldest one is learning at a primary school. The younger one is still little. Her family has a carpentry workshop. Her family's main income is from it. Hien is in charge of selling products for the workshop. Her husband is a carpenter. He earns about 10,000,000 VND. Hien is also a teacher and a farmer to earn a living. She has done this job for six years. She gains 3,000,000 VND per month. Her family’s total earnings are about 13,000,000 VND per month. Her challenge in life and work is the lack of capital to expand her family's business of capentry and lacking of her carpentry product's output. She wishes her children will grow up well and be successful in the future. This loan helps her get to this dream. She can invest in her carpentry workshop to gain earnings and save the profit for her children’s education. 

Hien is a hardworking woman and has a passion for business. She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2010. In the last loan cycle, she borrowed 8,288,000 VND and repaid on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,184,000 VND to buy wood for her carpentry workshop. She always wants to expand her business and raise her children well.

loans.use: to buy wood for her carpentry workshop

loans.name: Thuy's Group

texts.en:
Thuy is 33 years old. She has three children, two of whom are married and the other one is studying in 12th grade. Her husband works as a builder to earn a living. He earns about 3,000,000 VND per month. Thuy breeds chickens and grows fruit tree. She has done this job for seven years. Her family’s total earnings are about 3,500,000 VND per month. She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2007. In the last loan cycle, she borrowed 9,810,000 VND to invest in breeding chickens. In this new loan cycle, she would like to borrow 10,682,000 VND to buy 500 chickens and to buy guava seed to grow. She wants to her children to grow up well

Other members who are part of Thuy's group include the following:

Nam, 37 years old, has two children. She breeds pigs. She wants to borrow 8,938,000 VND to buy pigs
Thanh , 49 years old, has two children. She breeds pigs. She wants to borrow 7,630,000 VND to buy pigs.
Vinh, 63 years old, has two children. She breeds chickens. She wants to borrow 8,502,000 VND to breed chickens.
Nga, 33 years old, has two children. She sells chickens. She wants to borrow 9,810,000 VND to invest in her business.
Hoa, 53 years old, has two children. She breeds chickens. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to breed chickens.

loans.use: to buy guava seed to grow and 500 chickens

loans.name: Vuong

texts.en:
Vuong was born in 1993. He lives in Dong Anh, Hanoi. He learns computer science at Post and Telecommunication Institute of Technology. His course lasts four years and he will be graduated in 2016. He chose this major because of his passion for computers. He is the first person in his family to graduate from high school and go to study in college. 

His family has six members and their total income is about 8,000,000 VND per month. His mother (who is also in the photo) is a member of SEDA’s credit program, too. He is aware that studying will give him opportunities to find a good job and gain more money to feed his parents in the future when they are getting old. 

He wants to borrow 10,206,000 VND to buy a computer. This loan suits his family’s situation and income. The loan is disbursed fast and conveniently right after completing the paperwork. He appreciates this program and he will try his best to study and work for the best future.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Glecy

texts.en:
This is Glecy. She previously accessed an 15,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts, accessories and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan for her to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Glecy dreams to expand her business and hopes to have a good life. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and maintenance of their tricycle unit.

loans.name: Hong's Group

texts.en:
Hong is 45 years old. She has four children who are studying in intermediate college, secondary school, primary school and kindergarten. She and her husband sell fruits to earn a living. She earns about 6,000,000 VND per month and he earns about 3,000,000 VND per month. She has done this job for 10 years. Her family’s total income is about 9,000,000 VND per month. Her challenge in work is the lack of capital to sells fruits. Her dream is to build a new house. This loan is one of the step that helps her reach this dream. She is a passionate businesswoman. She has participated in SEDA’s credit program since 2007. In the last loan cycle, she borrowed 9,810,000 VND and repaid on time. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 10,682,000 VND to buy more fresh fruits to sell in her store.

Other members who are part of Hong’s group include the following:  

Loan is 49 years old. She has three children. She sells frozen foods . She wants to borrow 7,630,000 VND to develop her work 
Diu is 64 years old. She has three children. She is a farmer. She wants to borrow 9,810,000 VND to breed chickens. 
Huong is 43 years old. She has two children. She sells mechanical goods. She wants to borrow 6,322,000VND to develop her work.
Dau is 50 years old. She has two children. She sells vegetables. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to develop her work. 
Soi is 51 years old. She has three children. She sells scraps. She want to borrow 9,810,000 VND to develop her work.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fruits to sell in her store.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
This is Analyn. She previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she utilized to buy gardening materials and supplies needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children's education and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would now like to apply for a 10,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy fertilizer and garden inputs needed in her business. Her profits from his business will definitely help her cover their daily needs and her children's education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Analyn hopes to expand her business and dreams to have a good life with her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fertilizer and garden inputs needed in her business.

loans.name: Mafa

texts.en: Mafa is a 48-year-old married woman with six children. She has a small plantation and grows taro plants to earn a living. She has been doing this for many years. Mafa has requested a loan to buy a mist blower, chainsaw, fertilizer, bush knives, gloves and shovels. She has been a member of SBPD since 2011. With her profits, Mafa hopes to save for her family's daily needs.

loans.use: to buy a mist blower, chainsaw, fertilizer, bush knives, gloves and shovels.

loans.name: Santi Pala Group

texts.en:
Wayan, 49 years old, lives in a village in West Bali. He lives with his wife because his son is grown up and lives with his own wife. As the leader of Santi Pala group, he coordinates its members, both in terms of loans and business management. Total group borrowing was  23M IDR and Wayan got 1.5M IDR or 1M IDR. It was because of that he was able to set aside some of the profits he earned to be the business capital.

Wayan will use the loan to buy fertilizer and insecticide. This time he has planted corn and it needs to be cultivated and sprayed with insecticide to get good results. Wayan hopes he will have a good result so it is enough to save as well as repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticide

loans.name: Romulo

texts.en:
Romulo is a 61-year-old married man, a father of 5 children and the husband of a businesswoman. He lives in Balintawak, Aurora, Zambo. del Sur. Aside from farming, he used to manage their own store selling goods in the local community. He is now requesting an amount of 5,000 PHP to purchase canned goods, bottled products and noodles.

In the future he hopes to be able to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, bottled products and noodles.

loans.name: Richel

texts.en:
Richel is 37 years old and married. She is from Calabayan, Ozamis City. She has four children who have helped her in taking care of the bananas she raises. She has been raising bananas for years and earns 6,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) a month. She have to work hard now for she needs more funds for an additional expenses for her infant baby. 

Recently, she has requested a loan of PHP 5,500 to purchase fertilizer and to pay weeding costs. She hopes for a bountiful harvest and to expand her cultivated area.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and to pay for weeding costs.

loans.name: Lourdes Marianella

texts.es:
Lourdes es una mujer de 21 años, es soltera, vive en la ciudad de Ica en el distrito de Parcona con sus padres y hermanos, ella es una persona muy amable, trabajadora y entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo de superación; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad que tuvo de trabajar desde muy joven para ayudar a sus padres, Lourdes no ha podido estudiar la carrera profesional de Administración de Empresas que desea, en sus ratos libres le gusta relajarse escuchando música y en algunas ocasiones cocina unos riquísimos Chicharrones de Pollo para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, Lourdes trabaja brindando atención al cliente en un puesto de comida de un mercadillo de su ciudad, ella trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 10 horas y cree que le va bien por el trato amable que brinda a los demás.
Lourdes se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de una lavadora, la cual Lourdes brindará a su Madre para que trabaje, ya que ella da servicios de lavandería y debido al tiempo que se ha dedicado a esta labor ya no puede seguir lavando a mano pues sufre muchas dolencias, así pues Lourdes seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de poder estudiar una carrera profesional.
texts.en:
Lourdes is a single 21-year-old woman. She lives in the city of Ica in the district of Parcona with her parents and her siblings. She is a very kind, hard-working and enthusiastic person who has a great desire to rise above her situation. Unfortunately, due to a lack of economic resources and to the need for her to work from a young age in order to help her parents, Lourdes has not been able to study the professional career of Business Administration as she had hoped. In her free time she likes to relax while listening to music and occasionally cook some delicious chicken cracklings to share with her family.

Of her own initiative, and with determination and dedication, Lourdes works providing customer service in a food stand in a small market in her city. She works every day for about ten hours and believes that it's going well for her because she treats others so well.

Lourdes is very grateful to Kiva lenders, since it is thanks to this help given to her that she will be able to buy a washing machine. She will give it to her mother to use in her laundry business since she suffers many ailments due to the long amount time that she has dedicated to this job and can no longer wash clothes by hand. 

Lourdes will continue working and making an effort to achieve her dream of being able to study a professional career.

loans.use: to buy a washing machine.

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al Banco Comunal “Amistad Cusqueña”,el socio lleva buen tiempo dedicándose a esta actividad el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su trabajo, el socio es una persona responsable siendo de esta forma que el socio saca adelante a su familia.
El socio solicita el crédito para comprar llantas para su carro.
El socio se siente agradecido por el crédito y se compromete a pagar sus cuotas puntualmente.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the “Amistad Cusqueña” communal bank. He has been working in his activity for some time and it is going well for him thanks to the hard work he puts into his work every day. He is a responsible person and this is the way he get his family ahead. 

He is asking for the loan to buy tires for his car. He is is grateful for the loan and committed to making his payments on time.

loans.use: to buy tires for his car.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy an oven.

loans.name: Virgen De Chapi De Yanamaqui Group

texts.es: “VIRGEN DE CHAPI DE YANAMAQUI” es un nuevo grupo conformada por 07 socios con ganas de mejorar su calidad de vida. Alberto tiene 35 años es divorciado. Actualmente es maestro de construcción. Se inicio como ayudante albañil se siente contento por los logros que ha obtenido en su vida personal. El préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de herramientas de construcción: escuadra, palustre, llana dentada, nivel. Su mayor deseo es seguir capacitándose en construcción para dar buenos servicios a sus clientes. El grupo agradece a los inversionistas KIVA por el préstamo brindado. Alberto ese encuentra  sentado en el medio viste camisa blanca.
texts.en: “VIRGEN DE CHAPI DE YANAMAQUI” is a new group made up of 7 members who want to improve their quality of life. Alberto is 35 years old. Right now, he is a construction foreman. He started as a bricklayer's assistant. He is happy with what he has accomplished in his personal life. He will invest the loan in buying construction tools: a set level, a trowel, a notched trowel, and a level. His biggest wish is to keep training in construction to give their customers good service. The group thanks the Kiva investors for the loan. Alberto is seated in the middle wearing a white shirt.

loans.use: to purchase construction tools such as a set square, a trowel, a notched trowel and a level.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 40 years old and married with 3 children between the ages of 7 and 15. She runs a palm oil business in Tombo Western rural area in Sierra Leone. She started this business to make her daily living. Her husband is a driver, but his income is not enough to support the family's living costs. She began this business to improve her life. 

She's been in this business since 2000 and sells palm oil within her community. She says that at present her business is doing well. Because of the profits, she has been able to take of her family.

Marie requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more palm oil to resell. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and have a permanent business location. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cement, lime and iron rods to change the roof on her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase an iron gate.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
Aminata, 38, is married with 5 children between 8 years and 19 years. She runs a palm oil business in Waterloo 2 Eastern area in Freetown. She started her business because she wants to be independent. 

She's been in this business since 2005 selling fried cakes within the community. She describes her major hardships as inadequate funds to run her business and transportation problems.  

Aminata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more flour, sugar and cooking oil to expand her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and repay her loan. In the future, she would like to expand her business more than even now. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more flour, sugar and cooking oil to expand her business.

loans.name: Martín

texts.es:
Martin es una joven de 29 años de edad, unido, tiene 5 hijas; ellos viven en  Caserío Los Yaxón, Aldea El Tablón, municipio de Sololá, departamento de Sololá.
Don Martín trabaja como albañil, construyendo casas tanto en su comunidad como fuera de ella. Este oficio lo aprendió de su padre porque él de niño lo ayudaba a construir. Con esta labor el genera los ingresos necesarios para el sostenimiento de sus hijas y de su esposa. Como padre responsable y preocupado por la vida de su familia desea mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda
Además del trabajo de albañil, él se dedica a la agricultura que también le ayuda a generar ingresos complementarios para el sostenimiento de su familia
El solicita un préstamo de Q 4,000.00 para compra de cables y alambre para la instalación de energía eléctrica en su vivienda
Sueña con mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda a través de la aplicación de acabados en su casa y la construcción de un muro de contención.
texts.en:
Martin is a 29 year old young man.  He is married and has five daughters.  They live in Caserío Los Yaxón, in the village of El Tablón, town of Sololá, department of Sololá.  Martin is a construction worker and builds houses both in his community and in the surrounding area.  He learned this trade from his father because as a child, he helped him build.  With this job, he generates the income he needs to support his wife and daughters.  As a responsible father that is concerned about his family’s life, he wishes to improve his housing conditions.

In addition to working as a construction worker, he is engaged in farming and this also helps him generate complimentary income to support his family.  He is requesting a loan of $525.00 to purchase cables and wire for installation of electricity in his home.  His dream is to improve his housing conditions by applying finishes in his home and building a retaining wall.

loans.use: to purchase cables and wire for installation of electricity in his home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional soaps, shampoos and cleaning supplies along with bonnets to continue offering bonnet cleaning services to her clients.

loans.name: María

texts.es:
María es una mujer de 21 años de edad, soltera, actualmente vive en  el Caserío Monte Mercedes, Cantón Sacsiguan, municipio de Sololá, departamento de Sololá
Ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de ropa y específicamente de trajes típicos que la gente de su comunidad usa. La elaboración de la ropa lo realiza en la casa donde vive. La venta de este producto la lleva a cabo con sus vecinos y también lo vende en el mercado de Sololá. Esta actividad la realiza porque es algo que tiene mucha demanda y le genera los ingresos necesarios para aportar al sostenimiento de su familia. 
Lleva 5 años realizando esta labor; además de esta actividad ella también se dedica a la venta de verduras en Santa Lucía Cotzumalguapa, departamento de Escuintla (costa sur de Guatemala).
Ella solicita un préstamo de Q 7,000.00 para compra de hilo para la elaboración de mas trajes típicos.
Sueña con ampliar la venta de verduras a través de la adquisición de otro punto de venta y con ello incrementar sus ventas y ganancias
texts.en:
Maria is a 21 year old single woman.  She lives in Caserío Monte Mercedes, canton of Sacsiguan, town of Sololá, department of Sololá.  She is engaged in making and selling clothing, specifically traditional costumes worn by the people in her community.  She makes the clothing in her home.  She sells this product to her neighbors and also sells it at the Sololá market.  She is engaged in this activity because there is a high demand and the business generates the income she needs to support her family.

She has been engaged in this work for five years.  In addition to this activity, she is engaged in selling vegetables in Santa Lucía Cotzumalguapa, department of Escuintla (in the southern coast of Guatamala).  She is requesting a loan of $900.00 to purchase thread to make more traditional costumes.  Her dream is to expand her fruit sales by acquiring another point-of-sale and, in this way, increase her sales and profits.

loans.use: to purchase thread to make more traditional costumes.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia is a 46-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has an 18-year-old daughter.

She engages in fishing and she sells the fish to customers in the community. She has been selling fish for more than 10 years. Aside from fishing, she also runs a sari-sari (variety) store. She sells goods including cooking oil, eggs, noodles, coffee, soaps and dry goods. 

She requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy fishing materials and to purchase additional stocks for the store. In the future, Antonia would like to expand her fishing business and also to save for her child's education.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials and to purchase additional stocks for the store.

loans.name: Anselma

texts.en:
Anselma is a 64-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has six grown children. 

She and her husband engage in fishing. He catches the fish and she sells them to earn a living. She has been selling fish for more than 10 years. 

To be able to pursue the family's livelihood, Anselma requested a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy fishing materials like fishing net, fuel for the pump boat, and lift weights. In the future, Anselma would like to expand her fishing business to provide good food and a sustainable livelihood.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like fishing net, fuel for the pump boat, and lift weights.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is a married woman from the town of San Miguel, Bohol. She runs a sari-sari or variety store business selling various goods and items to the people in her place. 

Julieta is asking for a loan to buy more stocks to sell like canned goods, candies, soda, biscuits and beverages, soap and toiletries. With this, she will be able to improve her store and attract more buyers, thus augmenting her sales and income. In the future, Julieta hopes to make her business a success.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell like canned goods, candies, soda, biscuits and beverages, soap and toiletries.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is 48 years old and married. She has two children.

Alicia works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from tailoring.

Alicia requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items like eggs, rice, shampoo, spices, soap, etc., to sell.

Alicia has borrowed and paid 13 loans from NWTF before this loan. 

Alicia aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items like eggs, rice, shampoo, spices, soap, etc., to sell.

loans.name: Riley

texts.en:
As an independent insurance agent, Riley has studied natural disasters and the federal, local and individual response in their aftermath. More than that, he has studied how to respond, taken several government-sponsored natural disaster response classes, and became certified to teach emergency preparedness. 

He is so passionate about educating others about how to be prepared for natural disasters and other emergencies that he decided to he would establish his own company, called Continuity Man. He offers emergency preparedness training to schools and businesses, and offers free advice through his radio show on 550 KTSA Radio, which broadcasts throughout South Texas.

“There is a huge disconnect between government programs out there and the average citizen,” Riley said. “Homeland Security through FEMA, they have a wide-reaching public awareness campaign, but still the connection between emergency responders, police, fire,  EMS and FEMA in the more serious disasters, what first responders do and what they are able to produce and what the average citizen understands is their responsibility.”
 
Riley said most people don’t understand that the scope of assistance that the federal government can offer is limited.

“There were many lessons from Hurricane Katrina that weren’t learned that should have been common knowledge,” Riley said.  “And while Homeland Security through FEMA has a wide-reaching public awareness campaign, there is still a disconnect in people’s understanding. I have found a gap in education that I am trying to help fill.”

In establishing his business model for emergency preparedness education, Riley learned about Accion Texas Inc. through the City of San Antonio's small business liaison.

Riley is using his $5,450 loan to fund advertising, to hire professionals to help him produce a high quality radio program, and to pay for air time. 

He said he is having success in acquiring clients and in building his show. 

“It’s been going really well,” Riley said. “Without Accion Texas, I would not have been able to get the money I needed for the programming.”

loans.use: to fund advertising, hire professional sound engineers, and pay for air time.

loans.name: Melarda

texts.en:
Melarda is a married woman and a mother of four children from Bien Unido, Bohol. 

Melarda is engaged in a food and vegetable vending business. This is the source of her income.

Melarda is asking for a loan to buy more stocks to sell like vegetables and cooking ingredients and materials for house repair like cement and wood. With this, she will be able to improve her store and attract more buyers. Melarda hopes to make her business a stable source of their income.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell like vegetables and cooking ingredients and materials for house repair like cement and wood.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn works hard to support her family. Evelyn is married and has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines. Evelyn applied for a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle. Evelyn has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Evelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for the maintenance of the motorcycle she uses in her transport business.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda is 47 years old, married, and has 3 children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Imelda has a business buying and selling rice in the Philippines. Imelda applied for a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional bags of rice to sell. Imelda has been in this business for 15 years. In the future, Imelda would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional bags of rice grains to sell.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en: As a married parent of four children, Joan works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from motorcycle transport. Joan is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase additional materials for her fishing business. Joan has been maintaining her business activities with her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for her fishing business.

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
As a married parent of seven children, Alejandra works hard to support her family.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling dried fish. Alejandra is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell for her fish vending business.

Alejandra has been sustaining her business activities through her past 21 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell

loans.name: Lorelyn

texts.en:
Lorelyn is 43 years old and married with four children.

Lorelyn works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items like eggs, rice, Nescafe, sugar, oil, groceries, etc. to sell.

Lorelyn has borrowed and repaid 15 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for six years and also earns an income from buying and selling rice.

Lorelyn aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items like eggs, rice, Nescafe, sugar, oil, groceries, etc. to sell

loans.name: Berlie

texts.en:
Berlie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buying and selling banana business in the Philippines. Berlie has been in this business for three years. She earns additional income from farming vegetables and rice and running a general store.

She is borrowing PHP 17,500 through NWTF to purchase additional bananas to sell for her buying and selling banana business.

Berlie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas to sell.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion is 59 years old and married with eight children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Concepcion has been raising pigs for 10 years and also earns additional income from fishing.

Concepcion is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Cole

texts.en:
As two former bomb diffusion technicians, Cole and Erik are no strangers to challenges.  Upon exiting the military in 2010, they felt a deep responsibility to contribute to social change and provide a way of saying “Thank you” to veterans.  Thus the idea of repurposing real bullets into bottle openers was created, with a goal to raise funds for veteran-focused groups.

The mission of Bullets2Bandages is to provide simple ways for every American to show their support and gratitude for veterans.  They donate 15% of all their profits to veteran-focused groups, including the The Travis Manion Foundation.  Cole and Erik believe strongly in the power of social responsibility and social innovation.  Together they strive to create a company that is responsible in its business practices and always has a cause.  Within their company they try to hire veterans, helping them transition into the civilian workforce.  

Two years after starting out, their business has grown into a dedicated warehouse and employs seven full-time employees.  However, what is most remarkable about their business is the strong community they’ve built on social media.  Their Facebook page has over 130,000 followers who are all passionate about supporting veterans!

Cole and Erik’s $10,000 Kiva loan will be used to streamline their business processes and fund new product development.  With your help, Cole and Evan can continue to give back to veterans and their families in need of support.

A message from Cole and Erik: “Thank you to everyone in the Kiva community.  The support that each of you gives inspires entrepreneurs to succeed across the world and changes people’s lives.  In the future, we plan to come back to Kiva and invest in other business ventures and to continue to be a part of the Kiva community.”

For more information on Bullets2Bandages, visit their Facebook page at http://www.facebook.com/Bullets2Bandages

loans.use: to streamline their business processes and fund new product development

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Edna works hard to support her family.

She has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling chickens. 

Edna is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy additional vegetables like tomatoes, eggplants, onions, garlic, etc. to sell for her vegetable vending business.

Edna has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables like tomatoes, eggplants, onions, garlic, etc., to sell.

loans.name: Eleonor

texts.en:
